content.title: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
content.summary: Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency is a common cause of megaloblastic anemia characterized by impaired DNA synthesis leading to macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils. Unlike folate deficiency, B12 deficiency causes neurological manifestations including subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord due to its role in myelin synthesis.
key_points: Causes megaloblastic anemia with MCV typically >100 fL
Neurological symptoms (paresthesias, ataxia) distinguish from folate deficiency
Pernicious anemia (autoimmune gastritis) is most common cause in developed countries
Elevated methylmalonic acid (MMA) and homocysteine are diagnostic
Treatment with parenteral or high-dose oral B12 reverses hematologic but not always neurologic deficits
content.statement: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia through impaired DNA synthesis and may produce irreversible neurological damage through demyelination if not promptly diagnosed and treated.

explanation.intuition: B12 is like a molecular recycling enzyme - it converts homocysteine back to methionine and methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Without it, these substrates accumulate, DNA synthesis stalls in rapidly dividing cells (blood, GI), and myelin production fails in neurons.
explanation.key_insight: The 'methyl trap' hypothesis: Without B12, folate becomes trapped as methyltetrahydrofolate and cannot participate in DNA synthesis, explaining why both deficiencies cause identical megaloblastic anemia but only B12 deficiency causes neurological symptoms.
explanation.technical_details: B12 serves as cofactor for two enzymes: (1) Methionine synthase - transfers methyl group from methylTHF to homocysteine; (2) Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase - converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. MMA elevation is specific to B12 deficiency while homocysteine is elevated in both B12 and folate deficiency.

definitions_glossary.cobalamin: Vitamin B12, a cobalt-containing water-soluble vitamin essential for DNA synthesis and neurological function
definitions_glossary.intrinsic_factor: Glycoprotein secreted by gastric parietal cells required for B12 absorption in terminal ileum
definitions_glossary.pernicious_anemia: Autoimmune destruction of gastric parietal cells leading to intrinsic factor deficiency and B12 malabsorption
definitions_glossary.megaloblastic_anemia: Anemia characterized by large RBC precursors (megaloblasts) due to impaired DNA synthesis
definitions_glossary.hypersegmented_neutrophils: Neutrophils with ≥5 lobes, pathognomonic finding in megaloblastic anemia
definitions_glossary.subacute_combined_degeneration: Demyelination of dorsal and lateral columns of spinal cord due to B12 deficiency
definitions_glossary.methylmalonic_acid: Metabolite elevated specifically in B12 deficiency due to impaired methylmalonyl-CoA mutase
definitions_glossary.homocysteine: Amino acid elevated in both B12 and folate deficiency due to impaired methionine synthesis
definitions_glossary.transcobalamin: Transport proteins (TC I, II, III) that carry B12 in blood; TC II delivers B12 to cells
definitions_glossary.Schilling_test: Historical test measuring B12 absorption with and without intrinsic factor (largely replaced by anti-IF antibodies)
definitions_glossary.methyl_trap_hypothesis: Theory explaining how B12 deficiency secondarily impairs folate function
definitions_glossary.holotranscobalamin: Active B12 bound to transcobalamin II, earliest marker of B12 deficiency

pathophysiology.mechanism: Impaired DNA synthesis in rapidly dividing cells and defective myelin synthesis
key_pathways: B12 deficiency → Methionine synthase dysfunction → Homocysteine accumulation
Folate trapped as methylTHF → Impaired thymidine synthesis → Defective DNA synthesis
Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase dysfunction → MMA accumulation → Abnormal fatty acid synthesis in myelin

absorption.requirement: Intrinsic factor from gastric parietal cells

laboratory_findings: Low serum B12 (<200 pg/mL definitively low, 200-300 borderline)
Elevated MMA (>0.4 μmol/L) - specific for B12
neurological: Posterior column dysfunction (loss of vibration/position sense)

differential_diagnosis: Folate deficiency (no neurological symptoms, normal MMA)

parenteral.regimen: 1000 μg IM daily × 7 days, then weekly × 4 weeks, then monthly for life

oral.mechanism: 1% passive absorption independent of intrinsic factor
oral.efficacy: Comparable to IM in patients without severe neurological involvement

monitoring: MMA and homocysteine normalize with treatment
Neurological recovery variable - may be incomplete if delayed treatment

definition.@value: A nutritional deficiency causing megaloblastic anemia and neurological dysfunction due to impaired DNA synthesis and myelin metabolism from lack of vitamin B12 (cobalamin)

scopeNote.@value: Distinguished from folate deficiency by neurological manifestations and elevated methylmalonic acid

medicalCode.description: Vitamin B12 deficiency anemia due to intrinsic factor deficiency (pernicious anemia)

learning_objectives: Describe the biochemical roles of vitamin B12 and consequences of deficiency
Explain the methyl trap hypothesis linking B12 to folate metabolism
Differentiate B12 deficiency from folate deficiency clinically and biochemically
Identify causes of B12 deficiency including pernicious anemia
Outline diagnostic workup including serum B12, MMA, and anti-IF antibodies
Describe treatment regimens and expected response
clinical_pearls: MMA is specific to B12 deficiency; homocysteine is elevated in both B12 and folate deficiency
Neurological symptoms can occur without anemia - never delay treatment
Neurological damage may be irreversible if treatment is delayed >6 months
High-dose oral B12 (1000-2000 μg) is as effective as IM in most cases
Check B12 before starting folate - folate can mask B12 deficiency and worsen neurological damage
Reticulocyte crisis at 5-7 days confirms response to therapy
common_misconceptions: B12 deficiency always causes anemia - neurological symptoms can precede anemia
Oral B12 doesn't work - 1% passive absorption is sufficient with high doses
Normal B12 level excludes deficiency - functional deficiency can occur with low-normal levels

citations.authors: Green R, Allen LH, Bjørke-Monsen AL, et al.
citations.title: Vitamin B12 deficiency

sources.source: Green R, et al. Vitamin B12 deficiency. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2017;3:17040.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill, 2022.
UpToDate. Clinical manifestations and diagnosis of vitamin B12 deficiency. 2024.
